information:
Post Malone has received five nominations for the 60th Academy of Country Music (ACM) Awards, scheduled for May 8, 2025. His nominations include Album of the Year for "F-1 Trillion," and three nominations for his collaboration with Morgan Wallen, "I Had Some Help." He is not nominated for the top category, Entertainer of the Year. Key competitors include first-time nominee Ella Langley, who leads with eight nominations. Other heavily nominated artists are Morgan Wallen and Lainey Wilson with seven nominations each, and Chris Stapleton with six nominations.

The reception for cross-genre artists at country music award shows has been mixed historically. Favorable precedents include Beyoncé winning a CMA Award for a collaboration with The Chicks, and Justin Timberlake winning a CMA with Chris Stapleton. Lil Nas X also won CMA Awards for "Old Town Road." However, many artists crossing over face resistance from traditional voters, and the Album of the Year award typically goes to established country artists. Post Malone himself has a history of receiving numerous Grammy nominations without winning; at the 2025 Grammy Awards, he was nominated for eight awards and lost all of them, bringing his career total to 18 nominations without a win.

Post Malone has recently made high-profile moves into the country music scene. His country album, "F-1 Trillion," has had strong commercial performance. He has engaged in collaborations with established country stars such as Morgan Wallen, Luke Combs, Blake Shelton, and Jelly Roll. His recent performance at the Coachella festival featured a country-focused set and guest appearances from Jelly Roll and Ed Sheeran. However, this performance received a mixed reception from viewers and critics.

forecast.no_outcome_scenario: ACM voters coalesce around core-country favorites (e.g., Lainey Wilson, Chris Stapleton, Morgan Wallen solo, rising first-timer momentum), and “I Had Some Help” is viewed as too pop-leaning to win Single/Song/Music Event/Visual; Album of the Year goes to an established country artist. Post is shut out across all his categories.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: “I Had Some Help” converts one of the collaboration-centric categories (most plausibly Music Event or Single of the Year; possibly Song or Visual Media). Even if Album of the Year goes elsewhere, a single category win suffices for a Yes.
forecast.rationale: Knowns: The ACMs are on May 8, 2025. Post Malone has multiple nominations (reports range 4–5), including Album of the Year for F-1 Trillion and several for the Morgan Wallen collaboration “I Had Some Help.” Competition is strong (Lainey Wilson, Morgan Wallen, Chris Stapleton; Ella Langley reportedly leads nominations). Cross-genre entrants can face resistance with country-voting blocs, but blockbuster collaborations have won before, and ACMs have rewarded commercially dominant tracks. “I Had Some Help” was one of the biggest songs of the period and gives Malone multiple paths to a win.  Base-rate/structure: Artists with 4–5 ACM nominations, including a category anchored by a massive hit, usually have better-than-even odds to take at least one award. Even with conservative per-category odds (e.g., 35–50% across Single/Music Event, 25–35% for Visual/Song, 10–20% for Album), the probability of being shut out across all categories is moderate but not high. The presence of Morgan Wallen on the collaboration likely helps in ACM voting more than it hurts.  Why not higher: • Some voters may penalize pop-crossover perception, especially in Song and Album categories. • Competition is unusually deep; it’s plausible one or two rival tracks split the major song/single votes, and a different collaboration or video wins Music Event/Visual. • Narrative risk: voters could aim to spotlight core-country stalwarts or breakout newcomers.  Why not lower: • Multiple “shots on goal” tied to a juggernaut hit make a complete shutout less likely. • Historical precedent for high-profile collaborations winning at country awards. • Strong commercial footprint and high visibility in the country lane over the past year.  What would move me up: Credible reporting or expert odds concentrating around “I Had Some Help” as the consensus frontrunner in Music Event or Single; final ballots chatter suggesting strong industry support; confirmation he indeed has five nominations including both Music Event and Single. What would move me down: Clear consensus that a rival song is sweeping Single/Song, indications of voter pushback against crossover acts this cycle, or confirmation that he has fewer relevant nominations than reported. Overall, given multiple viable paths to at least one win, I lean Yes but keep a buffer for competitive uncertainty and possible cross-genre hesitation.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Post Malone win an award at the 60th Academy of Country Music Awards?

Question background:
The awards are scheduled to be held on May 8, 2025. Malone has 4 nominations.


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Post Malone wins an award at the [60th Academy of Country Music Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/60th_Academy_of_Country_Music_Awards).




Your research assistant's report says:
Post Malone has received five nominations for the 60th Academy of Country Music (ACM) Awards, scheduled for May 8, 2025. His nominations include Album of the Year for "F-1 Trillion," and three nominations for his collaboration with Morgan Wallen, "I Had Some Help." He is not nominated for the top category, Entertainer of the Year. Key competitors include first-time nominee Ella Langley, who leads with eight nominations. Other heavily nominated artists are Morgan Wallen and Lainey Wilson with seven nominations each, and Chris Stapleton with six nominations.

The reception for cross-genre artists at country music award shows has been mixed historically. Favorable precedents include Beyoncé winning a CMA Award for a collaboration with The Chicks, and Justin Timberlake winning a CMA with Chris Stapleton. Lil Nas X also won CMA Awards for "Old Town Road." However, many artists crossing over face resistance from traditional voters, and the Album of the Year award typically goes to established country artists. Post Malone himself has a history of receiving numerous Grammy nominations without winning; at the 2025 Grammy Awards, he was nominated for eight awards and lost all of them, bringing his career total to 18 nominations without a win.

Post Malone has recently made high-profile moves into the country music scene. His country album, "F-1 Trillion," has had strong commercial performance. He has engaged in collaborations with established country stars such as Morgan Wallen, Luke Combs, Blake Shelton, and Jelly Roll. His recent performance at the Coachella festival featured a country-focused set and guest appearances from Jelly Roll and Ed Sheeran. However, this performance received a mixed reception from viewers and critics.

Today is 2025-04-22.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
